titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Helene Mullins and Marie McCall Papers
titlestmt.author: by Drew Adan and Lisa Conathan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 04:17

did.unittitle: Helene Mullins and Marie McCall papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Helene Mullins and Marie McCall Papers consists of correspondence, writings, and photographs by and relating to the American authors and sisters Helene Mullins and Marie McCall. Correspondence is highly fragmentary, consisting chiefly of letters from Jean and Zohmah Charlot and John Hall Wheelock to Helene Mullins. Photographs depict Mullins and McCall from childhood to later adulthood, and also include portraits and snapshots of family members and friends. Writings include drafts of Mullins's poetry, an autobiographical novel by Mullins entitled The Loving are Daring, and the unpublished diaries of Marie McCall.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Serendipity Books on the Elizabeth Wakeman Dwight Memorial Fund, 1999.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Helene Mullins and Marie McCall Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Helene Mullins and Marie McCall Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Former call numbers: Uncat ZA MS 626, Uncat ZA File 406

Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit. This collection was processed, including organization into series and listing, in 2013.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Helene Mullins (1899-1991)
bioghist.p: Helene Mullins (née Gallagher), American poet and novelist, was born in New York City in 1899, and was active from the 1920s (by which time she had already married Ivan Mullins) through the 1960s. She and her sister Marie McCall collaborated on their first novel, Paulus Fy (New York: Robert M. McBride & Company) in 1924. Mullins's breakthrough as an author came when a novel, Convent girl , and a volume of poetry, Earthbound & other poems , were published by Harper and Bros. in 1929. In 1935 she was involved in a near-fatal car accident, and soon thereafter she and McCall moved to Hollywood, California, for a lengthy convalescence. Except for this period, and time spent in Washington, D.C., during the Second World War, Mullins lived her entire life in New York City. She continued to publish poems (under the name Mullins, though she later married Linné Johnson) in journals and collected volumes until 1970. Helene Mullins died in Manhattan in 1991.

bioghist.head: Marie McCall (circa 1903-1986)
bioghist.p: Marie McCall (née Gallagher), American author and painter, date of birth recorded variously as circa 1903 or 1909. Marie McCall and her sister Helene Mullins spent much of their early adulthood living and working together. They collaborated on their first novel, Paulus Fy (New York: Robert M. McBride & Company) in 1924. McCall also published The Evening Wolves (New York: John Day Company, 1949), a novel inspired by Salem witchcraft. Born in New York City, McCall spent much of the latter half of her life in Woodstock, New York, where she died in 1986.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Helene Mullins and Marie McCall Papers consists of correspondence, writings, and photographs by and relating to the American authors and sisters Helene Mullins and Marie McCall. Correspondence is fragmentary, consisting chiefly of letters from Jean and Zohmah Charlot and John Hall Wheelock to Helene Mullins. Photographs depict Mullins and McCall from childhood to later adulthood, and also include portraits and snapshots of family members and friends. Writings include drafts of Mullins's poetry, an autobiographical novel by Mullins entitled The Loving are Daring , and the unpublished diaries of Marie McCall.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Helene Mullins Papers, 1870-1985. II. Marie McCall Papers, 1934-circa 1980.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Correspondence, Photographs, and Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Helene Mullins Papers consists of correspondence, writings, photographs, and printed material that document the life and work of author Helene Mullins. Correspondence is fragmentary, consisting chiefly of letters from John Hall Wheelock and Jean and Zohmah Charlot. Writings of John Hall Wheelock and of Jean Charlot are filed with their correspondence. Photographs include snapshots and studio portraits of Mullins's parents, of Marie McCall, of the Charlot family, and of other friends, colleagues, and family members, dating from the late nineteenth century through the 1980s. Writings include a typescript draft of an unpublished novel, The Loving are Daring , as well as poems and prospectuses.

did.unittitle: Catalogue of the Prints of Jean Charlot , printed version
What Do You Do With a Book? , by Jean and Zohmah Charlot, proofs
Obra Pictoria de Jean Charlot , printed version
"A Forgotten Novel of American Catholicism," review of Helene Mullin's Convent Girl , typescript
"Prayer to the Sun," poem, holograph, and greeting card
"Silence (in memory of my father)," poem, holograph

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title. Reviews of various works are filed at the end.

did.unittitle: "Chronicle of the Lives of Two Sisters" (prospectus for a novel), typescript
"Literary Reminiscences (Writers I have Known)" (prospectus for a memoir), typescript, copy
Reviews of writings by Helene Mullins

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Diaries and Writings. Diaries are arranged chronologically and writings are arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Marie McCall Papers includes diaries of Marie McCall from 1934 to 1977, including some transcripts, a draft of the novel Living Together , and other writings of Marie McCall.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Diaries are arranged chronologically, followed by transcripts.

did.unittitle: Transcript of letters from Seamus, typescript

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title. Untitled works are filed at the end.

did.unittitle: Nathaniel Moleskin and the Chinese Princess and Other Stories , printed
We are the Same Life , typescript
Chapters from and unfinished biography of Louis Eilshemius, typescript
